elements.content: <ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">A coordination polymer containing the d-block, s-block metal ions and NTA<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand, in which the unusual coordination mode of NTA<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand has been found for the first time, is constructed by self-complementary self-assembly process.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

A coordination polymer containing the d-block, s-block metal ions and NTA3- ligand, in which the unusual coordination mode of NTA3- ligand has been found for the first time, is constructed by self-complementary self-assembly process.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">The reaction of the flexible ligand nitrilotriacetate with Cu(acac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> under hydrothermal condition gave a unique 3D coordination polymer, NaCuNTAH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (NTA<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>the anion of nitrilotriacetate). Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ion plays an important role in chargeable and structural complementarity in the construction of 3D coordination framework. The unusual coordination mode of NTA ligand has been found for the first time. The complex is an example of coordination polymer containing the d-block, s-block metal ions and NTA<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand generated by an unusual self-complementary self-assembly process.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

The reaction of the flexible ligand nitrilotriacetate with Cu(acac)2 under hydrothermal condition gave a unique 3D coordination polymer, NaCuNTAH2O (NTA3- =the anion of nitrilotriacetate). Na+ ion plays an important role in chargeable and structural complementarity in the construction of 3D coordination framework. The unusual coordination mode of NTA ligand has been found for the first time. The complex is an example of coordination polymer containing the d-block, s-block metal ions and NTA3- ligand generated by an unusual self-complementary self-assembly process.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The construction of 3D coordination polymers has been a field of rapid growth in supramolecular and material chemistry because of the formation of fascinating structures and their potentially useful ion-exchange, adsorption, catalytic, fluorescence, and magnetic properties . Consequently, a variety of 3D metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been prepared through taking certain factors into account, such as the coordination nature of metal ion and shape, functionality, flexibility, and symmetry of organic ligand . Since long, rigid bridge ligands  have been widely used to construct coordination polymers, thus formed metal–organic frameworks are normally robust and easy to preview their topologies. Recently, more and more flexible ligands are used in building up the supramolecular structures to meet the functional properties since the flexible ligand may exhibit interesting conformation and coordination versatility. Compared with rigid one, however, the flexible ligand is difficult to give perfect multi-dimensional structure in view of crystallography. The mixing of rigid and flexible ligand is a strategy often used to solve the problem. Nitrilotriacetic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>NTA) is a kind of saturated aliphatic multicarboxylate ligands and its flexibility is due to the rotation of the single-bonded carbon chains with high specificity for various polyvalent metal ions. We have noted that the structural characterized divalent d-block metal NTA<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> complexes are mainly the mixed ligand  except for {[CoNa(NTA) (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>
, while some trivalent lanthanide  and monovalent transition metal  complexes are the non-mixed ligand coordination polymers. Obviously, the situations involving the charge balance, stoichiometry and coordination site complementarity are more complicated in divalent metal complexes than mono- and trivalent metal complexes. More importantly, the results in the Cambridge Structure Database have shown that the coordination mode of NTA<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand in all the complexes reported in the references so far is only the tripodal-type in which all the three carboxylato groups and a nitrogen atom of a NTA ligand chelate to one metal center. At this point, the flexibility of NTA ligand has not been expressed.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The construction of 3D coordination polymers has been a field of rapid growth in supramolecular and material chemistry because of the formation of fascinating structures and their potentially useful ion-exchange, adsorption, catalytic, fluorescence, and magnetic properties . Consequently, a variety of 3D metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been prepared through taking certain factors into account, such as the coordination nature of metal ion and shape, functionality, flexibility, and symmetry of organic ligand . Since long, rigid bridge ligands  have been widely used to construct coordination polymers, thus formed metal-organic frameworks are normally robust and easy to preview their topologies. Recently, more and more flexible ligands are used in building up the supramolecular structures to meet the functional properties since the flexible ligand may exhibit interesting conformation and coordination versatility. Compared with rigid one, however, the flexible ligand is difficult to give perfect multi-dimensional structure in view of crystallography. The mixing of rigid and flexible ligand is a strategy often used to solve the problem. Nitrilotriacetic acid (H3NTA) is a kind of saturated aliphatic multicarboxylate ligands and its flexibility is due to the rotation of the single-bonded carbon chains with high specificity for various polyvalent metal ions. We have noted that the structural characterized divalent d-block metal NTA3- complexes are mainly the mixed ligand  except for {[CoNa(NTA) (H2O)3]⋅2H2O} n  , while some trivalent lanthanide  and monovalent transition metal  complexes are the non-mixed ligand coordination polymers. Obviously, the situations involving the charge balance, stoichiometry and coordination site complementarity are more complicated in divalent metal complexes than mono- and trivalent metal complexes. More importantly, the results in the Cambridge Structure Database have shown that the coordination mode of NTA3- ligand in all the complexes reported in the references so far is only the tripodal-type in which all the three carboxylato groups and a nitrogen atom of a NTA ligand chelate to one metal center. At this point, the flexibility of NTA ligand has not been expressed.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">We are interested in exploring the construction of the flexible coordination polymers. In this work, a new synthesis strategy has been designed and applied for NTA bridge ligand to construct 3D coordination framework. Here, the synthesis and crystal structure of 3D coordination polymers, NaCuNTAH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, have been studied.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: We are interested in exploring the construction of the flexible coordination polymers. In this work, a new synthesis strategy has been designed and applied for NTA bridge ligand to construct 3D coordination framework. Here, the synthesis and crystal structure of 3D coordination polymers, NaCuNTAH2O, have been studied.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Cu(acac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> has been used as the starting material to react with the NTA<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand. The title compound was synthesized hydrothermally at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C by treating a mixture of NTA (0.0192<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), NaOH (0.012<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) dissolved in 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml of distilled water and Cu(acac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (0.0393<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol ) in 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml methanol solution. Bright blue single-crystals were obtained after three days. IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3390.8 (m, <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">HO–H</ce:inf>), 3027.7 (m, <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">C–H</ce:inf>), 2962.0 (w, <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">as(CH2)</ce:inf>), 1641.4, 1562.7 (vs, <mml:math altimg="si1.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mrow>
<mml:msubsup>
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mi>ν</mml:mi>
</mml:mrow>
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mtext>as</mml:mtext>
<mml:mo stretchy="false">(</mml:mo>
<mml:mtext>COO</mml:mtext>
<mml:mo stretchy="false">)</mml:mo>
</mml:mrow>

</mml:mrow>
</mml:msubsup>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:math>), 1470.6, 1424.3 (s), 735.0, 695.6 (w).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Cu(acac)2 has been used as the starting material to react with the NTA3- ligand. The title compound was synthesized hydrothermally at 100°C by treating a mixture of NTA (0.0192g, 0.1mmol), NaOH (0.012g, 0.3mmol) dissolved in 5ml of distilled water and Cu(acac)2 (0.0393g, 0.15mmol ) in 10ml methanol solution. Bright blue single-crystals were obtained after three days. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3390.8 (m, ν HO-H), 3027.7 (m, ν C-H), 2962.0 (w, ν as(CH2)), 1641.4, 1562.7 (vs,     ν   as ( COO )   -    ), 1470.6, 1424.3 (s), 735.0, 695.6 (w).

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The IR spectrum of the complex shows the characteristic absorptions for the NTA<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> anion. The strong bands at 1601 and 1432<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> are assigned to <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">as</ce:inf> and <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">s</ce:inf> vibrations of <mml:math altimg="si2.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mrow>

. The disappearance of about 1745<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> suggests complete deprotonation of NTA ligands. The presence of water in the complex can be confirmed by the appearance of a broad band around 3300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (<ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">O–H</ce:inf>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The IR spectrum of the complex shows the characteristic absorptions for the NTA3- anion. The strong bands at 1601 and 1432cm-1 are assigned to ν as and ν s vibrations of     RCO   2   -     . The disappearance of about 1745cm-1 suggests complete deprotonation of NTA ligands. The presence of water in the complex can be confirmed by the appearance of a broad band around 3300cm-1 (ν O-H).

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">It has been reported that the acac ligand in Cu(acac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> can be replaced by the chelating ligand. The chelating ligand can attach the metal centers in the square-planar complexes along axial position, which can replace the acac ligand further. In this self-assembly process, the chelating acac ligand is replaced more difficultly than the coordinated water molecule by the carboxylato group of NTA ligand. It offers enough time for the NTA<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> anion to coordinate with different metal centers and avoid chelating to the same one to presenting the tripodal-type coordination mode.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: It has been reported that the acac ligand in Cu(acac)2 can be replaced by the chelating ligand. The chelating ligand can attach the metal centers in the square-planar complexes along axial position, which can replace the acac ligand further. In this self-assembly process, the chelating acac ligand is replaced more difficultly than the coordinated water molecule by the carboxylato group of NTA ligand. It offers enough time for the NTA3- anion to coordinate with different metal centers and avoid chelating to the same one to presenting the tripodal-type coordination mode.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The title complex has been characterized by the single-crystal X-ray crystallography . Each Cu(II) ion is connected with two nitrogen atoms and four carboxylato oxygen atoms which are come from the two NTA ligands (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>). Now, each of the two coordinated NTA ligands provided one nitrogen atoms and two of the three carboxylato groups. The remaining carboxylato group of a NTA ligand coordinated to two Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ions. This unusual coordination mode of NTA ligand is characterized as an extending mode and has been found for the first time. It indicates that the NTA ligand can construct flexible extending framework. All Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ions are five coordinated with oxygen atoms by four carboxylato oxygen atoms and a water molecule (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>). The Na–O bond lengths arrange from 2.247 to 2.495<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. There are four kinds of Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ions with slight different coordination environments based on the different Na–O bond distances and Na–O–Na bond angles. The average bond lengths of Na–O bonding for the different Na ions are 2.427 (Na1), 2.422 (Na2), 2.369 (Na3) and 2.364 (Na4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. These average distances are shorter than those in the complex of Na<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>[Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NTA)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4,4′-bpy)]ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O reported by Su which arrange from 2.298(3) to 2.607(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å . The discussions about the interaction between sodium and oxygen have been absent for a long time. Probably, it is due to the misconception that the Na–O bonding is strictly ionic and not interesting. In other hand, the crystallography data of the Na–O complexes is lack. Recently, there are some researchers who have paid their attentions to this area . Wood and Palenik has been used the bond valence sum (or BVS) method to calculate the Na–O bond lengths with different coordination numbers . The results tell us that the average distance of the Na–O coordination bond with coordination number 5 is between 2.368 and 2.443<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Thus, the Na–O bonds in the title complex are considered a typical Na–O coordination covalent bonding, not simply statistic interactions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The title complex has been characterized by the single-crystal X-ray crystallography . Each Cu(II) ion is connected with two nitrogen atoms and four carboxylato oxygen atoms which are come from the two NTA ligands ( ). Now, each of the two coordinated NTA ligands provided one nitrogen atoms and two of the three carboxylato groups. The remaining carboxylato group of a NTA ligand coordinated to two Na+ ions. This unusual coordination mode of NTA ligand is characterized as an extending mode and has been found for the first time. It indicates that the NTA ligand can construct flexible extending framework. All Na+ ions are five coordinated with oxygen atoms by four carboxylato oxygen atoms and a water molecule ( ). The Na-O bond lengths arrange from 2.247 to 2.495Å. There are four kinds of Na+ ions with slight different coordination environments based on the different Na-O bond distances and Na-O-Na bond angles. The average bond lengths of Na-O bonding for the different Na ions are 2.427 (Na1), 2.422 (Na2), 2.369 (Na3) and 2.364 (Na4)Å, respectively. These average distances are shorter than those in the complex of Na3[Cu2(NTA)2(4,4'-bpy)]ClO4 ⋅5H2O reported by Su which arrange from 2.298(3) to 2.607(4)Å . The discussions about the interaction between sodium and oxygen have been absent for a long time. Probably, it is due to the misconception that the Na-O bonding is strictly ionic and not interesting. In other hand, the crystallography data of the Na-O complexes is lack. Recently, there are some researchers who have paid their attentions to this area . Wood and Palenik has been used the bond valence sum (or BVS) method to calculate the Na-O bond lengths with different coordination numbers . The results tell us that the average distance of the Na-O coordination bond with coordination number 5 is between 2.368 and 2.443Å. Thus, the Na-O bonds in the title complex are considered a typical Na-O coordination covalent bonding, not simply statistic interactions.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The carboxylato oxygen atoms bridge the Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ions to form one-dimensional chain (Na(4)–O(3), 2.374; O(3)–Na(3), 2.330; Na(3)–O(8), 2.387; O(8)–Na(3A), 2.247; Na(1)–O(2), 2.399; O(2)–Na(1A), 2.297<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The extra one negative charge of the NTA ligand after coordinated with Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ion is balanced by Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ion. Not only this, Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ion as connector builds up the 3D coordination framework using strong coordination bond based on the above discussion. Therefore, the complex is a unique 3D heteronuclear coordination polymer containing transition metal and alkaline metal ions. Obviously, Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ion cannot be ignored and plays an important role in chargeable and structural complementarity in 3D structural construction of the complex. This kind of self-assembly can be defined as a self-complementary self-assembly. If Cu(II) ions are omitted in the structure, the 3D coordination framework is still exist, which are supported by Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> linked through carboxylato group (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>). No any solvent or guest molecule is sited in the channels of the framework.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The carboxylato oxygen atoms bridge the Na+ ions to form one-dimensional chain (Na(4)-O(3), 2.374; O(3)-Na(3), 2.330; Na(3)-O(8), 2.387; O(8)-Na(3A), 2.247; Na(1)-O(2), 2.399; O(2)-Na(1A), 2.297Å). The extra one negative charge of the NTA ligand after coordinated with Cu2+ ion is balanced by Na+ ion. Not only this, Na+ ion as connector builds up the 3D coordination framework using strong coordination bond based on the above discussion. Therefore, the complex is a unique 3D heteronuclear coordination polymer containing transition metal and alkaline metal ions. Obviously, Na+ ion cannot be ignored and plays an important role in chargeable and structural complementarity in 3D structural construction of the complex. This kind of self-assembly can be defined as a self-complementary self-assembly. If Cu(II) ions are omitted in the structure, the 3D coordination framework is still exist, which are supported by Na+ linked through carboxylato group ( ). No any solvent or guest molecule is sited in the channels of the framework.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) indicated that the simulated pattern is good in agreement with the experimental result of the complex. This tells us the phase purity of the as-synthesized product.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">In summary, we have used the self-complementary self-assembly strategy to construct 3D structure of Cu(II) with flexible NTA ligand. The extending coordination mode of NTA ligand has been found for the first time. The Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ions are responsible for chargeable and structural complementarity in the complex. The story tells us that the count-ions can play important roles in construction of coordination framework besides their charge balance. We are presently extending this result to another flexible ligand and looking forward to getting multifunctional crystalline materials.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) indicated that the simulated pattern is good in agreement with the experimental result of the complex. This tells us the phase purity of the as-synthesized product.

In summary, we have used the self-complementary self-assembly strategy to construct 3D structure of Cu(II) with flexible NTA ligand. The extending coordination mode of NTA ligand has been found for the first time. The Na+ ions are responsible for chargeable and structural complementarity in the complex. The story tells us that the count-ions can play important roles in construction of coordination framework besides their charge balance. We are presently extending this result to another flexible ligand and looking forward to getting multifunctional crystalline materials.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Supplementary material</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Crystallographic data for the structure reported in this paper has been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as supplementary publication numbers: CCDC 257806. Copies of the data can be obtained free of charge on application to CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK (fax: +44 1223 336 033; E-mail:<ce:inter-ref xlink:href="mailto:deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk" xlink:type="simple">deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk</ce:inter-ref>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Supplementary material

Crystallographic data for the structure reported in this paper has been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as supplementary publication numbers: CCDC 257806. Copies of the data can be obtained free of charge on application to CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK (fax: +44 1223 336 033; E-mail:deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Supplementary data</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at <ce:inter-ref xlink:href="doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2006.05.014" xlink:type="simple">doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2006.05.014</ce:inter-ref>.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Supplementary data</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">
<ce:display>
<ce:figure>
<ce:label>Fig. 4</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">The X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) pattern of the title complex (a) the simulated pattern and (b) the experimental pattern.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="fx2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:para><ce:para view="all">
<ce:display>
<ce:e-component>
<ce:label>Supplementary data</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Supplementary data.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="mmc1"></ce:link>
</ce:e-component>
</ce:display>
</ce:para><ce:para view="all">
<ce:display>
<ce:e-component>
<ce:label>Crystal structure</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Crystallographic data.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="mmc2"></ce:link>
</ce:e-component>
</ce:display>
</ce:para><ce:simple-para view="all">Single-crystal of the title complex with dimensional 0.80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp> 0.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.01 was carefully selected and mounted to a thin glass fiber, respectively. X-ray diffraction data were collected on Bruker-AXS CCD area detector with graphite monochromated molybdenum Kα (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) radiation at a temperature of 295<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>±<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. Unit-cell parameters were determined from automatic centering of 25 reflections and refined using the least-squares method. The diffraction data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects, and absorption (empirically from <ce:italic>ψ</ce:italic> scan data). No crystals showed significant decay. No extinction correction was necessary for all complexes. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined using full-matrix least-square techniques on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> using SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen-atoms are located geometrically and refined by mixed methods. Crystal Data: <ce:italic>M</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp> 415.81, triclinic. Space group: <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>-1, <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>9.5640(19), <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>9.6650(19), <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>90.47(3)°, <ce:italic>β</ce:italic>

<ce:inf loc="post">c</ce:inf>

elements.clean_text:
Supplementary data

Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2006.05.014.

Supplementary data

   Fig. 4  The X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) pattern of the title complex (a) the simulated pattern and (b) the experimental pattern.     

   Supplementary data  Supplementary data.     

   Crystal structure  Crystallographic data.     

Single-crystal of the title complex with dimensional 0.80× 0.05×0.01 was carefully selected and mounted to a thin glass fiber, respectively. X-ray diffraction data were collected on Bruker-AXS CCD area detector with graphite monochromated molybdenum Kα (λ =0.71073Å) radiation at a temperature of 295±2K. Unit-cell parameters were determined from automatic centering of 25 reflections and refined using the least-squares method. The diffraction data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects, and absorption (empirically from ψ scan data). No crystals showed significant decay. No extinction correction was necessary for all complexes. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined using full-matrix least-square techniques on F 2 using SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen-atoms are located geometrically and refined by mixed methods. Crystal Data: M = 415.81, triclinic. Space group: P-1, a =9.5640(19), b =9.6650(19), c =11.389(2)Å, α =90.47(3)°, β = 91.75(3)°, γ =111.24(3)°, V =980.6(3)Å3, D c =1.564gcm-3, Z =4, μ =1.245mm-1, R 1 =0.0377, wR 2 =0.1177. 90.47(3).

cln_elements.clean_text:
Cu(acac)2 has been used as the starting material to react with the NTA3- ligand. The title compound was synthesized hydrothermally at 100°C by treating a mixture of NTA (0.0192g, 0.1mmol), NaOH (0.012g, 0.3mmol) dissolved in 5ml of distilled water and Cu(acac)2 (0.0393g, 0.15mmol ) in 10ml methanol solution. Bright blue single-crystals were obtained after three days. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3390.8 (m, ν HO-H), 3027.7 (m, ν C-H), 2962.0 (w, ν as(CH2)), 1641.4, 1562.7 (vs,     ν   as ( COO )   -    ), 1470.6, 1424.3 (s), 735.0, 695.6 (w).

Supplementary data

Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2006.05.014.

Supplementary data

   Fig. 4  The X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) pattern of the title complex (a) the simulated pattern and (b) the experimental pattern.     

   Supplementary data  Supplementary data.     

   Crystal structure  Crystallographic data.     

Single-crystal of the title complex with dimensional 0.80× 0.05×0.01 was carefully selected and mounted to a thin glass fiber, respectively. X-ray diffraction data were collected on Bruker-AXS CCD area detector with graphite monochromated molybdenum Kα (λ =0.71073Å) radiation at a temperature of 295±2K. Unit-cell parameters were determined from automatic centering of 25 reflections and refined using the least-squares method. The diffraction data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects, and absorption (empirically from ψ scan data). No crystals showed significant decay. No extinction correction was necessary for all complexes. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined using full-matrix least-square techniques on F 2 using SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen-atoms are located geometrically and refined by mixed methods. Crystal Data: M = 415.81, triclinic. Space group: P-1, a =9.5640(19), b =9.6650(19), c =11.389(2)Å, α =90.47(3)°, β = 91.75(3)°, γ =111.24(3)°, V =980.6(3)Å3, D c =1.564gcm-3, Z =4, μ =1.245mm-1, R 1 =0.0377, wR 2 =0.1177. 90.47(3).

<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">The new coordination model of NTA<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Selected distances (Å): Cu(1)–O(1) 2.256(2), Cu(1)–O(6) 1.9223(19), Cu(2)–O(7) 2.3165(19), Cu(2)–O(12) 1.9438(19), Cu(1)–N(1) 20132(2), Cu(2)–N(2) 2.077(2), Na(1)–O(2) 2.297(2), Na(1)–O(9) 2.339(2), Na(1)–O(14) 2.448(3), Na(2)–O(9) 2.412(2), Na(2)–O(11) 2.332(2), Na(2)–O(14) 2.546(3), Na(3)–O(3) 2.330(3), Na(3)–O(5) 2.387(2), Na(3)–O(8) 2.247(2), Na(4)–O(3) 2.374(2), Na(4)–O(5) 2.268(2), Na(4)–O(10) 2.377(2), Na(4)–O(13) 2.282(2). Selected angles (°): N(1)–Cu(1)–O(1), 78.93(7); N(1)–Cu(1)–O(1)#1, 101.07(7); O(6)–Cu(1)–O(1), 91.80(9); N(2)–Cu(2)–O(7), 77.80(7); N(2)#2- Cu(2)–O(7), 102.20(7); O(12)–Cu(2)–O(7), 89.24(9). Symmetry transformations used to generate equivalent atoms: #1: <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>; #2: −<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, −<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, −<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>

</ce:figure>

metadata.title: Self-complementary self-assembly of 3D coordination framework involving d-block, s-block metal ions and flexible NTA3− ligand
